awd_titl_txt: Exploring the Dark Universe: Panoramic Imaging and Spectroscopy with the Subaru 8 meter Telescope
awd_abstract_narration:
This program will build a state-of-the-art database and user interface for the Subaru Measurements of Images and Redshifts (SuMIRe) sky survey.  SuMIRe is a 600-night imaging and spectroscopic widefield survey currently underway using the Subaru 8-meter Telescope on Mauna Kea in Hawaii.  Broader impacts of the work involve training of undergraduate and graduate students in data processing, analysis, and management skills.  The program will recruit five undergraduates from underrepresented groups each year.  Summer workshops for students on a national basis will extend training beyond the home institutions.  

The following are major scientific goals: (1) provide a public portal to the SuMIRe survey data (images and spectroscopy) for the astronomical community, and (2) develop a processing pipeline for the Prime Focus Spectrograph (PFS) data that is part of the SuMIRe survey.  The multi-color imaging survey will be ~1400 sq. degrees to ~26 magnitude (much deeper but over a smaller field than Sloan Digital Sky Survey); the spectroscopic survey will cover 300 nights in 2019-2024 and will be based on targets from the imaging survey.

por.por_cntn:
The Prime Focus Spectrograph (PFS) is a spectrograph system that is mounted on the 8.2-meter Subaru Telescope in Hawaii. It consists of 2394 configurable optical fibers, which are situated in the Prime Focus Instrument (PFI). Light from these fibers are distributed to 4 identical Spectrograph Modules (SM). Each SM consists of detectors spanning the Blue, Red and Near-Infrared passbands.

The PFS Group at Princeton University have developed a processing pipeline that takes raw data from each SM, corrects for instrument artifacts and cosmic rays, extracts for a given exposure 2394 science spectra, subtracts bright sky lines and sky continua, and presents these data in an accessible form for the 1D Data Reduction Pipeline to determine stellar characteristics. As a necessary intermediate product, the pipeline also generates calibration data that will be regularly updated as the instrument characteristics change. This pipeline has been tested successfully on the visual (blue and red) bands for one Spectrograph Module currently installed at Subaru and will be exercised further when the 3 additional Spectrograph Modules, and their NIR cameras, are available.

Caltech have completed their contribution as to how Focal Ratio Degradation (FRD) from the individual optical fibers will affect the point spread functions of lines in the spectrograph, and how that will affect the subtraction of bright sky lines and the extracted science spectra. They:

1.     Characterized changes in FRD from preferably in-focus images, or if that is too difficult, from near-focus images taken with fine defocus motor shifts of up to 100 microns

2.     Developed algorithms to measure FRD as a function of Cobra position, which can be used to create initial FRD parameters used in the 2D DRP.

3.     Investigated hysteresis, to determine if there is any as the Cobras move in the long term.

4.     Delivered code that addresses the tasks above.

 

The Johns Hopkins University (JHU) team at the Institute for Data Intensive Engineering and Science (IDIES) were tasked with 4 components of this project: an asynchronous query facility, a database mirror, a spectrum analysis tool and an image archive mirror with cutout and mosaic services. They completed the first 3 tasks successfully. For the last task, they are pending approval from NAOJ.

 

A number of students benefitted from this project:

  • The PhD thesis of Brent Balland (Caltech) is based in large part on his work characterizing the FRD of the PFS fibers and Cobras. He completed his thesis in June 2021.
  • Through his work on the PSF modeling, Princeton Professional Specialist Neven Caplar is developing into a world leader in spectrograph optics. The fully physical approach he is taking is key for the PFS spectrograph and is likely to be the approach for future spectrograph projects as well.
  • In 2020, Sean Johnson ended his postdoctoral position at Princeton, and became an assistant professor in the Astronomy Department at the University of Michigan. The contributions he made to the simulation effort and testing of the 1D pipeline while a postdoc are sufficient to give him data rights for PFS in the future. 
  • Lina Florez, who worked on the project over several summers as an undergraduate, was admitted to graduate studies at the University of Pittsburgh, where she is working on galaxy evolution in the context of the PFS survey under the tutelage of Professor Rachel Bezanson.
